context: [6] However, recent evidence suggests that mitochondria may have a more profound role in T cell activation. [7] For example, mitochondria have been shown to accumulate at the immune synapse (IS) that T cells form with antigen-presenting cells (APC). [8] Mitochondria are thought to be necessary in order to regulate Ca2+ homeostasis and to generate reactive oxygen species that modulate signaling pathways downstream of the TCR/CD28 co-receptor . [1] Here we show that mitochondria play another critical role in T cell activation, namely the production of intracellular ATP that is released from stimulated cells in order to fuel the purinergic signaling mechanisms that regulate T cell activation at the IS. [2] Our findings indicate that mitochondria are gate-keepers of T cell activation that coordinate Ca2+ homeostasis with autocrine purinergic signaling processes to orchestrate the complex choreography of T cell activation events required for a successful immune response.
